nodes.description: Each controller has a shadowy colored hand. Looking at objects through the different hands reveals their "past" or "future" states and objects can be temporally moved by holding them and looking at them through the desired hand.

Moving the joystick locks the viewpoint and detaches the user's avatar which can be moved around to perform actions. The 3rd view avatar can move away from the user. At the press of a button the user is teleported to where the avatar is.

Architectural elements like doors or passages that connect two locations. The player and any object that crossess them moves from one location to the other. Some implementation allow to see the other side of the portal and they are used as redering methods.
nodes.similarity: Projected Portal, Impossible Portals, Teleport, Redirected Walking

nodes.description: Forward movement by swinging arms while pressing a button
The user (or the experience) make the viewpoint change from first person to to third person. First person allows interaction with the environment. Third person allows avatar locomotion.

move center of pressure on the board to move in that direction. Some boards use springs or the like and tilt with your center of gravity, some are isometric and simply detect your center of gravity without moving perceptibly. Although I haven't yet found a source earlier than 2015, the more complicated 3D Rudder was out for testing in early January so there must have been usable balance boards for VR earlier. The Wii Balance Board, a balance board for 2d, was released as early as 2007
Bob HMD to move forward after bouncing or pressing a button. Return to static after movement stops
The longer you hold the jump button, the higher you will rise in the VR space.
The user moves of a pre-determined distance in the looking direction by pressing a button
Players climb up walls, mounts and other objects by swinging their hands and pulling triggers to grab. Releasing the hands makes the player fall.

Player moves in the direction of joystic in discreet steps, similar to miniature teleportations. Objects prevent steps to happen. Large falls can be prevented by constraining movement direction or not allowing the jump.
using a stationary bicycle Pedaling and brakes control front/back motion. Handlebars control direction on the ground plane
Using robot platforms that appear just in front of the participant when they are about to step
The user interacts with props that resemble the controls of a vehicle and the movement resembles the physical motion of the vehicle
I can't imagine anything to enter a building that's not either a simple doorway you go through with your alternative locomotion, or is simply a subcategory of Architectural Portal tagging: ???

When performing movement on the ground plane using the controller, the player sees a box surrounding them with only a small floating window through it showing the play area and following the gaze with a delay . The box can be made disappear by pressing a button.

Simulation of EVA space suit through thrusters. Altough 6dof control is possible, this scheme usually provides 4dof control based on acceleration using two joystick controls (moving the stick generates acceleration on the corresponding dof). Control based on position rather than on acceleration could be implemented, some implementations include a control that stabilizes rotation.
The current scene or point of view fades out and a new one fades in
Wiggling fingers over one hand moves the player forward

Flapping hands to go higher, while player continuosuly moves forwards. Could also be done without controllers with hand-tracking cameras and direction of movement can be modified from "forward" to gaze with ease for better presence and manueverability.
Fly through the air with gaze as directional input or press one button to fly higher and another to go lower.
forward speed can be controlled by button, speed circle, or walking in place, direction is controlled by position of hand controllers or joystick.

To move small distances, Grip and drag the environment. To move large distances, place 2 focal points on the ground with the controllers then rotate, scale, and translate the world. Similar to Move and Scale but here the user can move only on the ground plane and points to the ground rather than grabbing air
hybrid with various standing and room-scale locomotion methods. combines bobbin, arm swing and climbing
grab environment push from it to locomote in 3D in the desired direction. Inertia allows to continue moving until new grab, or bouncing on objects

project a hook in the pointing direction to attach to parts of the environment, the rope allows swinging to move to a different location, some implementation have a blink teleportation to decrease nausea
the participant stands or seats on top of a physical platform that moves as the VR needs, providing vestibulat stimulation to the users
open hand to go forward, close it to go backward
propels in the direction opposite to the direction where the controller is pointed. Simulate two rockets at the end of the arms. Similar to EVA, but here the rockets can be oriented
use controllers as feet to move on the floor, can have visual extensions to increase speed. Can jump by pushing off the environment.
Initiating movement by looking in the direction you want to go. You tilt your head forward, you move forward. Tilt your head backwards, and you go backwards.
Users move by grabbing and pushing the world. A  sphere appears around the view point while moving, blurring the environment.

The user stands on a board suspended from the ceiling and is strapped into the same ropes the board hangs from. The user can safely tilt the board and more importantly their body while suspended to accelerate the in-game board based on the degree of tilt. Sense of vection and presence may depend strongly on how realistic it seems for the 'in-game' movement method to respond so subtly to your incline and sickness as well as presence depend heavily on sensor accuracy.

Fixed in place game elements that immediately move the player to a different locations. Some implementation allow to see the other side of the portal. They are used to allow loading and changing parts of the map.

The only real difference from the balance board is that the board can rotate freely. This aspect can likely only be properly used when sitting, although theoretically one could stand with outside support. I believe that the primary purpose of the rotation is to rotate the perspective, but then it's a little unclear how headset rotation affects that. I'm assuming they're simply added together and the board rotate's one's "foot position" and the headset changes one's torso and head rotation to affect the viewpoint? Possibly should be merged with balance board, but the difference in posture and newfound turning ability may be worthy of distinction.
based on the metaphor of a human-scale joystick, the user leans in the direction and with an angle that specify direction and speed.
The viewpoint changes smoothly and with high velocity on the ground, making a step in the viewing direction

Pull up an ingame minimap with controllers and select a location on the map to teleport there. There may likely be predetermined locations on the map one can teleport to and you need simply select one.
nodes.similarity: Impossible Portals, Architectural Portals, Cinematic Blink

nodes.description: movement forward proportional to height of jump

Press a trigger on controller to record your origin, lean beyond the boundary threshold to move in game, return to origin to stop. Effectively joyman with moment to moment calibration and an on/off button
Core experiences involve roomscale tracking,  movements across areas involve non-agency transition
move around the world by grabbing it with one hand, shrink and turn it with two hands. Similar to Focal Point but allows also to move vertically.
Stretch both arms in the opposite direction of your desired movement while lean in the same direction of desired movement
The user enters in a box that occludes the surroundings and when they enter they arrive to their destination
the location and/or orientation of the viewpoint changes according to a pre-determined sequence, could include a vehicle, the user doesn't have control
Run PocketStrafe app on the smartphone, place the smartphone in your pocket, run in place to move.

The player has the ability to project or attach two portals on world surfaces and move between them when crossing one. The player is able to perform other movements using other methods (e.g. 1:1, teleportation, slide)
Design the game in a way to allow the player to move in circles in the play area. Players will never hit physical walls of the play area.
Put hands at your hips, press a button on each controller and run in place to move
Entire play space becomes the inside of the vehicle, operate the controls in the vehicle to move the vehicle
move around the room in real physical space, limited by the room size, VR movement is mapped 1:1 with real movement
Predetermined movement of the user's perspective. The user has no control over the position of their reference frame but can control where they look.
Moving the controllers below the waist and then backwards causes the user to propel forward.
When the player is about to hit a wall in real life, the character in VR instantly turns 180 degrees (face backwards). It forces the player to turn around in real life in order to move forward again.
instantaneour clockwise/counterclockwise rotation steps by pressing button or moving joystick on the side
move hands forward to advance straight, move one hand more in front to go in that direction, move hands up to elevate
Hold the triggers and stroke or peddle.
draw path on the floor and either travel in steps through arm swinging or smoothly
The user points to one of few possible locations and by pressing a button instantaneously moves there

Aim in the direction you want to go (may need to press a button to activate), see a marker on the ground, press/release a button to instantaneously move to the location. Could see an “X” meaning the location is not reachable.
the user selects the position and direction to teleport to
In combat-based experiences, sucessive teleportations are paused for a period
The user throws an object or shoots an arrow to move instantaneously to the location where the object or arrow land

The user points in the intended direction and clicks on a button with one of the hand moving the user towards that direction. There are slight rotation towards the side of the hand that presses the button, forcing the user to alternate the pressing hand, thus simulating walking in place
The user moves of a short, pre-determined distance in the pointing direction by pressing a button.
user has a glimpse from the new position before teleporting there.
Player's POV trails behind their character, works for third-person games with gamepads

push stick and orient controller to move at constant speed with combined direction between the two. The direction is stick relative to controller relative to environment, so largely the direction the stick is being pushed in the real world.
The user moves around with constant speed and the view of the scene is shrinked as a function of speed and duration of motion, leaving the periphery black or rendering a simple  scene (google vr)
Press right bumper to fly up and press left bumper to fly down. Press and hold for smooth flight, or press and release for incremental movement.
interaction happens witin a 2D screen
The user points at the ground seeing a marker indicating the location and when pressing a button the user moves there instantaneously
The user moves by controlling a vehicle, which is visible to surround the user (i.e. in the form of a cockpit)
The users control the simulated flying dynamics of a vehicle through an interface or by modifying control surfaces with their posture
digitizing tablet: x and y motion yielded rotation about y and x respectively, and a circular stirring motion yielded rotation about z
point to the ground to see a marker and an arror. reorient the arrow to be teleported in that location and direction
uses movable or slippery surfaces to allow kinematic movement in place,  movements might not be limited to front/back, feet travel while in contact is mapped to vR movement
make step while physically not moving the body, each step makes the player advance or recede of a fixed amount

After reaching edge of playable space', virtual world is blurred and grid appears. Virtual world shifts to encompass open play area, forcing player to turn and face it. At this point the virtual world comes back into focus and grid disappears.
walking to the edge of the play area causes time to freeze and locks the world to the player's rotation. A HUD appears and shows the amount of open space in front of the player.
amplify acceleration movement along the horizontal plane and in the gaze direction to increase the users’ walking speed
the user becomes a giant and then through room scale locomotion you can travel much bigger distances. he can then re-scale to a normal size.

sers’ head displacement is scaled according to their position in the VE. If the user is in an interactive area requiring fine control the viewpoint will follow the real motion of the head, but while travelling across connecting spaces motion has progressively larger gains.

Front/back motion is controlled by a device that allows walking 
ordinarily used for physical fitness. Can include a steering interface to 
control direction on the ground plane.
A mechanism allows to phisically bring the users back to the center of a workspace while they freely walk around in any direction.

a large treadmill combined with a 
large manipulator to provide inertial forces to the walker. Used in CAVEs or larger spaces
Front/back movement is controlled throught the pedals of an unycicle-like device, direction on the ground plane is controlled by twisting the waist

Forward motion is controlled by alternately moving the feet on a device that is ordinarily used for physical fitness. Steering on the ground plane can be achieved with a joistick or twisting the ancles
lower body support that provides user with leg moving ability while sitting
Uses a device on a desk that can be grabbed and pulled/twisted with 6dof. Movement in VR changes as a function of the pull force and torque
simulate barrels over an obstacle course to combine walking backward on a barrel with walking forwards on stationary objects
simulates boat oars that can be grabbed and rotated to propel the boat when in water
simulates kayack where either one paddle passes through the controller or two small paddles are attached to a cotroller. The user propels the kayack by moving the paddle(s) in water
app to change locomotion method, combines arm swinging, jumping and strafing by turning the controllers
User changes gravity direction by pointing, making the avatar fall along the gravity direction
Haptic feedback is provided as a function of walked distance or to simulate avatar's steps

User grasps the head and throws it. Pressing a button teleports the rest of the body to the location. Five levels of increased discomfort, where level 0 keeps the orientation of the camera matched to the HMD and level 4 matches camera orientation to the eye direction on the thrown head.
The viewpoint changes smoothly and with high velocity on the ground, making a step in the combined direction of joystick and viewing
The location changes when a cane touches the ground and is moved simulating the dynamic of a walking stick
The viewpoint changes smoothly and with high velocity on the ground, making a step in the direction where the user points
The user extends the hands and moves a ball surrounding the avatar. the ball follows its own dynamic, like a marble. Inspired by supermonkeyball game
User moves forward with constant speed when a button is pressed
Movement speed on ground proportional to joystic up to a max velocity. Direction is modulated by head and joystick
Movement are associated with body postures that leave hands free
When pressing a button, the user moves towards the pointing direction with fixed speed
